name: N-Queens
title: N-Queens
content:
The n-queens puzzle is the problem of placing n queens on an n x n chessboard such that no two queens attack each other.

Given an integer n, return all distinct solutions to the n-queens puzzle. You may return the answer in any order.

Each solution contains a distinct board configuration of the n-queens' placement, where 'Q' and '.' both indicate a queen and an empty space, respectively.

 

Example 1:

Input: n = 4
Output: [[".Q..","...Q","Q...","..Q."],["..Q.","Q...","...Q",".Q.."]]
Explanation: There exist two distinct solutions to the 4-queens puzzle as shown above

Example 2:

Input: n = 1
Output: [["Q"]]

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 9

discussion_posts.content: The king is getting smart. None of his queens could see each other and he could go and see anyone;)

discussion_posts.content: queens can attack other queen in the same row, same column, but i forget the  diagonal.. = \u3002=

discussion_posts.name: sanket_tle
discussion_posts.content: the dopamine hit after getting an ac on hard problem is crazy

discussion_posts.name: ICalmPersonI
discussion_posts.content:
If you didn't quite grasp the magic of "Backtracking" before, you'll fully understand it after this problem. It's not as daunting as it may seem, especially if you've tackled plenty of BFS/DFS problems before.
(The feeling of true euphoria isn't when you solve a difficult task, but when you finally fully understand something new that had been elusive for a long time.)

discussion_posts.name: Dhananjay40
discussion_posts.content: For n=2 and n=3, I think it is impossible to place queen by following the conditions.\nProblem description should have mentioned these constraints. Do we need to return empty list  for the same?

discussion_posts.name: Ebad1001
discussion_posts.content: For `n = 2` & `n= 3` , there exists no valid configurations.\nFor these testcases you have to return the empty list / array / vector.
